Author: jlangenauer
Content:
If you're using Rails:\n- searchlogic: incredibly easy searching of ActiveRecord models. I've cut out huge amounts of code by using this gem.\n- factory_girl: get rid of those awful fixtures!

Also, even though it's not a gem, JRuby is an awesome platform - I actually prefer it to MRI after using it. It's incredibly stable, fast, and bugs are fixed damn quick. I reported a bug in JRuby-OpenSSL yesterday at about 9am, and there was a fix done by 1pm. Very impressive.

Author: dbz
Content:
Absolutely not; however, I feel that Google made a big mistake. It released a Minimum Viable Product, which might have been okay for other companies to do, but because Google is such a large brand name- and such a large part of the internet- it is expected to come out with an amazing product.

A minimum viable product phone is simply not acceptable for someone like my mother who would by the phone because it has Google's name on it. (Yes. I understand that example has a fallacy or two, but it should make my point clear.)

On the other hand, I keep on getting more and more interested in this phone!

Author: rubinelli
Content: Most of Latin American countries are democracy, but until relatively recently, they were run by right-wing dictatorships. Generally speaking, their institutions are still recovering, the legislative branch is discredited, and the executive still concentrates an awful lot of power, making it very easy to slip back into caudillismo.

Author: Arun2009
Content:
> Therefore I can't blame people, if they don't know any better.

This sounds to me as patronizing. I refuse to think that Cameroonians "don't know any better".

I was not really speaking for Cameroon anyway. My main target was India, where you'll see the most demeaning, wretched kind of poverties. I am responsible for it, and if I choose not to do anything about it, then it's my deliberate choice. That's all I am saying.

> for example not everybody has the skills to become elected as president to be able to change the laws

We are not all born with the tools required for the things we need done. We acquire them over time.

Waiting for a messiah to materialize is what I'd call the Kalki-complex. Kalkis (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalki) are myths. If there's to be change, it must come from us. And that sense of responsibility is what would inspire each of us to strive to be mini-Kalkis, and with any luck, some of us might even become major-Kalkis.

Author: SwellJoe
Content: What do you do when your RV is in the shop? I had a propane tank issue that seemed like it was going to require an overnight stay (it didn't, as it was just a gasket), and I was a bit flummoxed by the problem. I guess I'm maybe traveling a little heavier than you (big dog, and three very expensive guitars that I wouldn't want to leave in the truck while it's out of my hands, along with way too much other crap that it seems like I'd need to sort out, like the food in the fridge), but still...since I'm not towing a car, I guess I'd need to first rent a car, then hand over the RV, and settle in at a nearby hotel for the duration of repairs. Seems stressful, but I guess I'll cross that bridge if I come to it.

Author: buro9
Content:
What do you need bandwidth for?

My father lived on a canal barge for the past 4 years and is now living in a custom RV. He loves the mobile life and dislikes being anchored to one spot too long.

He rents a virtual server with Linode for things that require constant monitoring, but it also provides him with a SSH tunnel for when he's using public internet.

He's parking in pub car-parks a lot of the time and as he's in the pub most evenings the landlords are happy with this. He uses their wi-fi (with permission) and gets great bandwidth and has his SSH tunnel to offer security.

When he's not parked with such favourable conditions he uses a 3G card which gives him decent reception everywhere. With a blackberry all of his email is taken care of so he only needs to get online to do specific things.

Now, granted he's not a programmer... but how much bandwidth does that SSH connection take? And if you're using a virtual server to do your downloads and then can drive by a wi-fi spot to collect them from the server then you would've successfully avoided the very expensive cost of a satellite connection.

Author: SwellJoe
Content: Sleeping in the vehicle is another matter; but since it's not obvious someone is sleeping in the vehicle, I suspect one can get away with parking legally and sleeping illegally enough of the time to make it worthwhile (if a ticket for sleeping in the vehicle costs, say, $75, then as long as you don't get ticketed more than once every three nights, you'd come out ahead over an RV park). There are other benefits to RV parks, including the convenience of not having to run the generator for power, not having to dump and refill water, and probably having better Internet, so I'll probably end up staying in parks about 75% of the time. I'm paying $41.50, including utilities and Internet, per night here in Morro Bay, and this is a pretty pricey area; my house in Mountain View cost $71.50 per night, and didn't include utilities or Internet. So, I'm still coming out way ahead.

Author: Tichy
Content:
I strongly disagree, I think it is more important to look at the system that brings about the results (poverty). Not everybody is in a position to change the system - for example not everybody has the skills to become elected as president to be able to change the laws.

Maybe everybody could do something to change things, but it certainly isn't obvious WHAT to do. Therefore I can't blame people, if they don't know any better.

Author: nostrademons
Content:
The first that comes to mind is the Ottoman empire. World power in the 1600-1700s, but it failed to develop the institutions mentioned in this article and fell to Austria-Hungary, Italy, and Britain over the latter half of the 1800s.

Lithuania. Largest country in Europe in the 14th century. Lost large sections of its territory to Sweden and Russia in the late 1600s and 1700s.

All of the Native American nations that were swept aside by the United States. Much of that was because of disease, but a lot was also because the U.S. was better organized and could pick off individual tribes one-by-one.

Mongolia. Genghis Khan's empire, once one of the largest on earth. Great fighters, poor administrators. Eventually overshadowed by China.

Author: lsc
Content:
I think it's interesting how /personally/ business owners take feedback. Especially at first, I know my stomach churned rather unpleasantly when I got even a mildly negative review. It's hard not to take it personally.

But how you end up handling that, I think, is super important. In my space, it's pretty easy to say "Oh, I'm sorry, would you like a refund?" First, taking responsibility for the problem, and then offering to refund what the customer paid seems to disarm even the most vocal critics. I mean, you don't usually get to keep the customer, but they usually stop saying bad things about you.

But really, being 'just a guy' is a little bit of a double-edged sword. you want to be 'human' enough that you seem like a person and not some faceless corporation, but you also need to maintain enough emotional distance that you respond in a polite manner (or don't respond at all) when someone insults the 'baby' you have spent the last 5 years of your life working on.

Author: Arun2009
Content:
I think the first step in overcoming poverty is for all of us to propagate a value system where citizens are held responsible for their countries.

For example, if India is poor and backward, then I am responsible for contributing to its poverty and backwardness, and so are all other Indians.

Author: blasdel
Content:
While there may be some intercorporate chicanery going on, I think that the "blame Andy Rubin" explanation makes the most sense.

The original Sidekick team designed Android originally before being bought by Google, and their intensely odd ideas show up all over the place in the product:

  * It makes really poor use of the Linux kernel, basically using it as a bootloader,
    hardcoding random shit, implementing its own power management by exposing a few
    low-level hardware-specific bits directly to their JVM
  
  * Bizarro JIT-less register-based alt-JVM. Aren't native apps supposed to be faster
    than web apps? WTF did they spend effort writing V8 when Squirrelfish was doing
    great, and then not bother about performance for the part that makes phone calls?
    
  * Odd decomposed 'Activity' model for applications
  
  * No house style or easy defaults for basic shit like buttons and forms
  
  * Huge holes in the API, sound is fucked to the point where you can't do decent
    games, much less the kind of musical apps you see on the iPhone
  
  * Hidden functionality via long-touches and double-clicks everywhere
  
  * 5 hardware buttons in different orders on random phones
    with different functionality in every app (back is completely fucked!)
Multitouch gestures in the default apps are just one of the lesser oddities.

Author: SwellJoe
Content: According to reviews Earth Class Mail is among the worst of these services (though they have better web design and better PR). PaperlessMail.com and sbimailservice.com are better reviewed, and the prices end up being a lot lower. I don't have enough experience to say what is best, or whether Earth Class Mail deserves its bad reputation, but I did spend a lot of time reading up on it, since it's pretty important that mail works right for me to be able to keep running Virtualmin.

Author: jan_g
Content:
>People often ask where it’s legal to park an RV. And the answer is, generally, “Wherever you can park your car, I can park my RV; as long as it fits, doesn’t obstruct signage or right of way, and doesn’t spill into another space where spaces are marked.” The law in most of California is that vehicles under 45 feet and used for non-commercial purposes can park anywhere any other consumer vehicle can park.

Interesting. This is not the case over here in Europe (at least in the parts of it I've been to). You get fined if you sleep overnight in your vehicle outside designated areas (like camping sites, specially RV-dedicated parking lots, etc., all of which you have to pay, of course).

EDIT: of course you can park everywhere, I was referencing "sleeping" part of the article.

Author: SwellJoe
Content:
I don't know yet. I'm waffling a bit. I ordered dishes which will be delivered to Palo Alto tomorrow...poor planning, as I should have waited until I was settled somewhere for a week or so before ordering them. So, I can either proceed with my "keep going south until it gets warm" plan and be without dishes for a couple of months until I get back up north, or detour back up to Palo Alto to pickup the dishes. I might also bother my friend who's receiving them to ship them out to me next time I settle somewhere. I also have solar panels coming that were supposed to be delivered several days before I left, but got delayed. I suspect I'll cancel the solar panels and just keep going south; Los Angeles, San Diego, maybe Mexico.

I think we're going to do a conference in February in Los Angeles, so I'll probably stay in California until then. We'll definitely be doing OSCON, so I'll be in Portland in July. I don't think I'll make YAPC this year, since it is across the country and doesn't leave a lot of time to get back to the left coast for OSCON (my goal is to drive no more than six hours between stops and never stop for less than a week, since I do have work to do and can't be driving all the time).

Author: metaguri
Content:
The other important reason to use a library is that if someone improves the algorithm someday, you can benefit for nothing more than installing and testing the new version of the library.

I remember this also being the case for Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP) algorithms in AI. If you can formulate your problem as a CSP and feed it to a library, you automatically benefit from future improvements in the field of CSP solvers.
